{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-265-08-A |Item_parent=Urinary lithiasis |Item_parent_short=Urinary lithiasis |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the clinical aspects of complicated renal colic |Description=Summary tables: according to clinical features (fever, anuria, pain) and condition (pregnancy, single kidney, HIV, etc.). |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors=Romain Boissier |Order=8}}
{| class="wikitable" |+ '''Table of clinical aspects of complicated renal colic''' trimester (24 ADT): paracetamol or morphine from the outset Imaging: ultrasound or non-injected 1.5T MRI: 1sttrimester but difficult in emergency practice or low-dose CT (<4 mSv) 2-3rd trimesters (< 20 mGy). -1st intention monitoring: expulsion 70-80%. -renal urine diversion: if pain, PAD, pre-eclampsia, fever, renal failure - catheter or nephrostomy: no recommendation - change every 4-6 weeks |'''Febrile renal colic = acute obstructive pyelonephritis = severe acute pyelonephritis''' |Fever >38.5°C, chills, skin mottling, haemodynamic instability, positive urine dipstick. |- |Renal colic with acute renal failure |Congenital or acquired single functional kidney Or bilateral stones (rare) oligo-anuria < 500cc / 24h |- |Hyperalgesic renal colic |Nephritic colic resistant to NSAID and morphine administration |}
